channel.title: Comments on: What tools do you use?

item.title: By: Jens Polster
item.dc:creator: Jens Polster
item.description: <p>I'd add wink to the list for creating tutorials and SnagIt for screenshots.<br />I have been working with both, MartinScott Noteman and Ytria scanEZ and must say i prefer scanEZ (no issues with both). The Ytria tools have a much cleaner UI and more features (plus other tools like signEZ etc).</p>
item.content:encoded:
I’d add wink to the list for creating tutorials and SnagIt for screenshots.
I have been working with both, MartinScott Noteman and Ytria scanEZ and must say i prefer scanEZ (no issues with both). The Ytria tools have a much cleaner UI and more features (plus other tools like signEZ etc).

item.title: By: Scot
item.dc:creator: Scot
item.description: <p>Yea, I had a few issues with Ytria as well. Switched to the MartinScott tool a few years back and have not had any trouble with it. I use it daily. Real time saver.</p>
item.content:encoded: Yea, I had a few issues with Ytria as well. Switched to the MartinScott tool a few years back and have not had any trouble with it. I use it daily. Real time saver.

item.title: By: Matt White
item.dc:creator: Matt White
item.description: <p>@1 - I've downloaded Coda and had a look, very nice, I can see another purchase on the horizon.<br /><br />@2 - Sounds excellent, I'll go and check it out.<br /><br />Matt</p>
item.content:encoded:
@1 – I’ve downloaded Coda and had a look, very nice, I can see another purchase on the horizon.

@2 – Sounds excellent, I’ll go and check it out.

Matt

item.title: By: Julian Robichaux
item.dc:creator: Julian Robichaux
item.description: <p>DDSearch is another good freebee for Notes. It allows you to search for text strings anywhere in the design of a Notes database. Thomas Gumz wrote it, so you know it's got to be good...<br /><img alt="Emoticon" src="<a rel="nofollow ugc">http://www.11tmr.com/11tmr.nsf/emoticons/DLYH-5MZVLU/$File/wink.gif"</a> /> <br /><br />Just do a search for "DDSearch" in the Notes.net Sandbox and you'll find it (the link is a little long to paste in here).<br /></p>
item.content:encoded:
DDSearch is another good freebee for Notes. It allows you to search for text strings anywhere in the design of a Notes database. Thomas Gumz wrote it, so you know it’s got to be good…
http://www.11tmr.com/11tmr.nsf/emoticons/DLYH-5MZVLU/$File/wink.gif“ />

Just do a search for “DDSearch” in the Notes.net Sandbox and you’ll find it (the link is a little long to paste in here).

item.title: By: Ben Poole
item.dc:creator: Ben Poole
item.description: <p>I would concur with your list, pretty much. I used XMLSpy for a while, but to be honest, it's too full-featured for me, got in the way.<br /><br />+1 for TextPad: love it. With regards a general purpose web-oriented editor on the Mac, the new love of my life is Coda. Lovely bit of kit that, very productive!</p>
item.content:encoded:
I would concur with your list, pretty much. I used XMLSpy for a while, but to be honest, it’s too full-featured for me, got in the way.

+1 for TextPad: love it. With regards a general purpose web-oriented editor on the Mac, the new love of my life is Coda. Lovely bit of kit that, very productive!
